O'Brien of The International Herald Tribune.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Stolen Facebook IDs and All About Zelda

docs.abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Tuesday, selections include Google Maps adding information on North Korea, a computer virus that has stolen thousands of Facebook log-in credentials, and a book that tells how all the versions of a popular video game fit together.

docs.abstract: Advertising column on aspect of online commerce that critics say finances online piracy: advertising; University of Southern California's Annenberg Innovation Lab ranks 10 ad networks on amount of business they do with sites suspected of engaging in piracy, with Google and Yahoo high on list.

headline.seo: Google Maps’ New Target: Secretive North Korea
headline.main: A New Target for Google Maps: The Streets of North Korea
headline.print_headline: A New Target for Google Maps: The Streets of North Korea

docs.abstract: Google Maps uploads map of North Korea, complete with street names and landmarks in Pyongang, providing peek at place previously shrouded in secrecy; North Korea is last country in world to get relatively detailed map; new map, which replaces old, mostly blank one, was built with help of citizens, including those who have fled country.
